Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.

<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_softirq_set_enable:
```c
static void metal_softirq_set_enable(struct metal_irq_controller *cntr,
				     int irq, unsigned int enable)
{
	if (irq < cntr->irq_base ||
	    irq >= (cntr->irq_base + cntr->irq_num)) {
		return;
	}

	irq -= cntr->irq_base;
	if (enable ==  METAL_IRQ_ENABLE) {
		atomic_store(&metal_softirq_enabled[irq], 1);
	} else {
		atomic_store(&metal_softirq_enabled[irq], 0);
	}
}
```
</target_code>

int irq_num

suspicious_frags:
static void metal_softirq_set_enable(struct metal_irq_controller *cntr,
				     int irq, unsigned int enable)
explanation: The only parameter modification in the function is the reassignment of the parameter 'irq' (irq -= cntr->irq_base;), which directly violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 (a function parameter should not be modified). The pointer parameter 'cntr' is only dereferenced to access members (cntr->irq_base, cntr->irq_num) and is not reassigned, which is allowed (the object referred to by a pointer may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not). The 'enable' parameter is read-only and not modified. The atomic_store calls modify elements of metal_softirq_enabled, not any function parameters. Therefore no other fragments require investigation under Rule 17.8.
